Text saved: A 'mindset' is how you think about things.

Carol Dweck studies how people think. She works at a big school. She gave some problems to ten-year-old children. The problems were a little bit too hard for them.

One group of children was happy. They liked hard problems. They knew they could learn and get better. She says these children had a 'growth mindset'. This means they think they can learn and get better. These children thought about what they can do later.

But another group of children felt bad. They thought someone was judging how smart they were. They felt they did not do well. These children had a 'fixed mindset'. This means they thought they could not change. They could not think about getting better.

Some children said they might copy answers later. Other children looked for someone who did worse. This made them feel better.
Feedback received: Grade 3/10 - FAIL
